title: Cannon v. SC Department of Probation, Parole and  Pardon Services
description: John Cannon appeals from an order requiring him to submit a DNA sample as a condition of his parole.  Cannon argues the statute was amended to exclude him from the DNA requirement and forcing him to provide a sample violates the ex post facto clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John Hall Cannon, Appellant,

v.
South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3871
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  11, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard A. Harpootlian and M. David Scott, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Teresa A. Knox, Deputy Director of Legal Services, Tommy Evans, 
  Jr., Legal Counsel and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  John Cannon appeals from an 
  order requiring him to submit a DNA sample as a condition of his parole.Â  Cannon 
  argues the statute was amended to exclude him from the DNA requirement and forcing 
  him to provide a sample violates the ex post facto clauses 
  of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Cannon was convicted of murder in April 
  1972 and was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  He subsequently pled guilty to 
  two additional counts of murder and received concurrent life sentences for those 
  two counts.Â  All three murder counts arose out of the same occurrence.Â  
On October 12, 1983, the South Carolina Department 
  of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (the â€œDepartmentâ€) released Cannon 
  from prison.Â  He was to remain under the Departmentâ€™s supervision for the remainder 
  of his life and was required to â€œcarry out all instructions [his parole agent] 
  gives,â€ but was not required to submit a blood sample as a condition of his 
  release.Â  Twelve years later, South Carolina enacted the State Deoxyribonucleic 
  Acid Identification Record Database Act (the â€œDNA Actâ€), found in sections 23-3-600 
  to 700 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), which require a person â€œcurrently 
  paroled and remaining under supervision of the Stateâ€ to provide a DNA sample 
  as a condition of his or her parole.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(C) (Supp. 1995); 
  Act No. 497, 1994 S.C. Acts 5816-5817.Â  In July 2000, the DNA Act was amended 
  to require a DNA sample from a person â€œconvicted or adjudicated delinquent before 
  July 1, 2000, who is serving a probated sentence or is paroled on or after July 
  1, 2000.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(E) (Supp. 2003).Â  In February 2001, the 
  Department notified Cannon that he was required by law to provide a DNA sample 
  as a condition of his parole and failure to do so would be considered a violation 
  of his parole.
In March 2002, Cannon instituted a declaratory 
  judgment action, seeking a determination whether the DNA Act requires, as a 
  condition of his parole, that he submit a DNA sample for inclusion in the DNA 
  database.Â  Cannon also sought and was granted a temporary restraining order 
  precluding the Department from requiring him to submit a DNA sample while the 
  case was pending in court.
A non-jury trial was convened on May 27, 2003.Â  
  On August 1, 2003, Judge Barber signed an order finding the DNA Act applied 
  to Cannon and required him to submit a DNA sample as a condition of his parole.Â  
  Judge Barber also determined the DNA Act did not violate the ex post 
  facto clause of the United States Constitution.Â  On August 19, 2003, 
  Cannon filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 52 and 
  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, which was denied on September 10, 2003.Â  Cannon appeals.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWe have held that where a law case is tried by 
  a judge without a jury, his findings of fact have the force and effect of a 
  jury verdict upon the issues, and are conclusive upon appeal when supported 
  by competent evidence.â€Â  Chapman v. Allstate Ins. Co., 263 S.C. 565, 
  567, 211 S.E.2d 876, 877 (1975).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Statutory Construction  
Cannon claims the DNA Act does not require him 
  to submit a DNA sample as a condition of his parole because he was released 
  on parole prior to July 1, 2000.Â  We disagree.
Cannon argues the trial court erred by determining 
  the word â€œparoledâ€ is synonymous with the phrase â€œremaining on parole on or 
  after July 1, 2000â€ because the legislature excluded the phrase â€œremaining under 
  supervisionâ€ from the amended statute.Â  Cannon asserts the 2000 amendments to 
  the statute materially changed the DNA Act by substituting language that requires 
  DNA samples from only those persons convicted of the specified offenses who 
  are â€œparoled on or after July 1, 2000.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(E) (Supp. 
  2003).Â  Cannon concludes the legislature intended a departure from the original 
  law by excluding those offenders paroled prior to the effective date of the 
  amendment, and therefore he is not required to provide a DNA sample under the 
  amended act because he was paroled prior to July 1, 2000.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.â€Â  Strother 
  v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 
  121 (1998).Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one 
  that the legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered 
  in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the 
  intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, 
  Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994).Â  While the â€œwords used 
  [in a statute] must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort 
  to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand its operation[, t]he language 
  must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords 
  with its general purpose.â€Â  Hitachi Data Systems Corp. v. Leatherman, 
  309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œHowever plain the ordinary 
  meaning of the words used in a statute may be, the courts will reject that meaning 
  when to accept it would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not 
  possibly have been intended by the Legislature or would defeat the plain legislative 
  intention.â€Â  Kiriakides, 312 S.C. at 275, 440 S.E.2d at 366.Â  Â Â 
The stated purpose of the DNA Act is to â€œdevelop 
  DNA profiles on samples for law enforcement purposes and for humanitarian and 
  non-law enforcement purposes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-610 (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 
  23-3-620 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) lists the classes of offenders 
  who are required by the act to provide a DNA sample for the DNA database and 
  states when the samples are to be taken.Â  In particular, the revised statuteâ€™s 
  section (C) pertains to an individual who is in prison and has not been released 
  on parole, and section (E) pertains to an individual who has already been released 
  on parole.
While the revised statuteâ€™s meaning is not clear 
  on its face, when section 23-3-620(C)(1) and (E)(1) of the South Carolina Code 
  (Supp. 2003) are read in tandem, it becomes apparent that the legislature intended 
  to require individuals who were placed on parole prior to July 1, 2000 and who 
  are still on parole after July 1, 2000 to provide a DNA sample as a condition 
  of their parole.Â  
Section 23-3-620(C)(1) requires an individual who 
  is serving a term of confinement on or after July 1, 2000 to submit a DNA sample 
  as a prerequisite of his or her parole, should they be released on parole in 
  the future.Â  Section 23-3-620(E)(1) requires that an individual who is paroled 
  on July 1, 2000 or later also submit a DNA sample as a condition of their parole.Â  
  Therefore, Cannonâ€™s interpretation of the statute, which would only require 
  a sample from individuals granted parole after July 1, 2000, renders section 
  23-3-620(E)(1) duplicative of section (C) because under section (C) those same 
  individuals would have already given a sample before being released.
Thus, when read as a whole, section 23-3-620 appears 
  to have been intended to cover all individuals who commit the enumerated crimes, 
  including those already in prison or out on parole.Â  Construing the statute 
  in light of its intended purpose, there is no logical reason why Cannon and 
  other similarly situated individuals should be excluded from the statuteâ€™s requirements.Â  
  To do so would result in the exclusion of a large number of individuals and 
  would frustrate the purpose of the legislation, which is to create an extensive 
  DNA database.Â  
Because such an exception does not appear to have 
  been intended by the legislature and there is evidence to support the trial 
  courtâ€™s findings of fact, the trial court was correct in concluding that individuals 
  who were placed on parole prior to July 1, 2000, and who are still on parole 
  after July 1, 2000, are required by section 23-3-620 of the South Carolina Code 
  (Supp. 2003) to provide a DNA sample for the State DNA Database.Â  
II.Â  Ex Post Facto  Clause  
Cannon also claims extending his term of incarceration 
  solely because of his failure to provide a DNA sample violates the ex 
  post facto clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.Â  
  We disagree.
While both the United States 
  and South Carolina Constitutions specifically prohibit ex post 
  facto laws, two critical elements must be present for a law to fall within 
  the prohibition: (1) the law must apply to events that occurred before its enactment, 
  and (2) the offender of the law must be disadvantaged by the law.Â  State 
  v. Walls, 348 S.C. 26, 30, 558 S.E.2d 524, 525 (2002).Â  Additionally, â€œ[f]or 
  the ex post facto clause to be applicable, the statute 
  or the provision in question must be criminal or penal in purpose and nature.â€Â  
  Id.
The DNA Act meets the two elements of the ex 
  post facto prohibition because the act applies to individuals 
  who were placed on parole prior to the July 1, 2000 amendment, and Cannon has 
  been disadvantaged because his parole will be revoked if he fails to provide 
  a DNA sample; however, the ex post facto clause is not 
  applicable because the actâ€™s purpose and nature is not criminal or penal.
â€œ[T]he determination whether a statute is civil 
  or criminal is primarily a question of statutory construction, which must begin 
  by reference to the actâ€™s text and legislative history.â€Â  In re Matthews, 
  345 S.C. 638, 648, 550 S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001).Â  â€œWhere the legislature has manifested 
  its intent that the legislation is civil in nature, the party challenging that 
  classification must provide â€˜the clearest proof that the statutory scheme is 
  so punitive in either purpose or effect as to negate the [legislatureâ€™s] intention.â€™â€Â  
  Id. (quoting Seling v. Young, 531 U.S. 250 (2001)).Â  
Section 23-3-610 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 
  2003) states the DNA Actâ€™s purpose is to â€œdevelop DNA profiles on samples for 
  law enforcement purposes and for humanitarian and non-law enforcement purposes, 
  as provided for in Section 23-3-640(B).â€Â  Section 23-3-640(B) lists seven uses 
  for a DNA sample collected under the DNA Act:

  
    
      
         (1)  
         to develop a convicted offender database 
  to identify suspects in otherwise nonsuspect cases;
      
      
         (2) 
         to develop a population database when personal 
  identifying information is removed;
      
      
         (3)   
         to support identification research and protocol 
  development of forensic DNA analysis methods;
      
      
         (4) 
         to generate investigative leads in criminal 
  investigations;
      
      
         (5)
         for quality control or quality assurance 
  purposes, or both;
      
      
         (6) 
         to assist in the recovery and identification 
  of human remains from mass disasters;
      
      
         (7) 
         for other humanitarian purposes including 
  identification of missing persons.
      
    
  

 S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-640 (Supp. 2003).Â  Thus, the legislatureâ€™s 
  intent was to create a statute that is civil in nature, and Cannon must prove 
  the DNA Act is so punitive in either purpose or effect as to negate the legislatureâ€™s 
  intention.Â 
While this is an issue of first impression in South Carolina, 
  it is not unique in terms of litigation concerning DNA acts across the nation. 
  [1] Â  Inmates who were required to provide a DNA sample under Virginiaâ€™s 
  DNA act attacked the constitutionality of the state statute on ex post 
  facto grounds.Â  Jones v. Murray, 962 F.2d 302, 308 (4th Cir. 1992).Â  
  The court held that Virginiaâ€™s requirement that inmates provide a DNA sample 
  is not punitive in nature and the testing itself did not violate the ex 
  post facto clause.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, the court held that 
  the statuteâ€™s possible effect of â€œauthorizing prison punishment, the denial 
  of good-time credits, or consideration by the parole board in granting discretionary 
  parole to compel the inmate to provide a sample, [does not violate the ex 
  post facto clause] because it does not thereby alter any prisonerâ€™s 
  sentence for past conduct.â€Â  Id. at 310.
Because the South Carolina legislatureâ€™s intent 
  appears to have been to protect the public, and not to punish those individuals 
  who commit or have committed the specified crimes, South Carolinaâ€™s DNA Act 
  is non-punitive and does not constitute a criminal penalty.Â  Cf. Walls, 
  348 S.C. at 31, 558 S.E.2d at 526 (holding the sex offender registry was intended 
  to protect the public from sex offenders who may re-offend and to aid law enforcement, 
  not to punish offenders).Â  Also, Cannon has failed to provide any evidence that 
  the DNA Act is so punitive in effect as to negate the legislatureâ€™s intent to 
  create a civil statute.Â  
Accordingly, the trial judge was correct in determining 
  the DNA Act does not violate the ex post facto clauses 
  of the United States or South Carolina Constitutions.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The courts in the following cases determined DNA database statutes 
    are not penal in nature and do not violate the ex post facto 
    clauses: Gilbert v. Peters, 55 F.3d 237 (7th Cir. 1995); Rise v. 
    State of Oregon, 59 F.3d 1556 (9th Cir. 1995); Shaffer v. Saffle, 
    148 F.3d 1180 (10th Cir. 1998); Kruger v. Erickson, 875 F. Supp. 583 
    (D. Minn. 1995).

description: Don Reno Walton pled guilty to charges of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a school.  He appeals, arguing the circuit court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to accept his guilty plea to distribution within proximity of a school.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Don Reno Walton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3872Â Â 
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed October 11, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all 
  of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Don Reno Walton pled guilty 
  to charges of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine 
  within proximity of a school.Â  He appeals, arguing the circuit court did not 
  have subject matter jurisdiction to accept his guilty plea to distribution within 
  proximity of a school.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
At the plea proceeding, Walton waived presentment 
  in writing and pled guilty to both of the above charges.Â  The charges stemmed 
  from his alleged sale of crack cocaine to a confidential informant on or about 
  April 3, 2001 in York County.Â  Walton was sentenced to time served and ordered 
  to pay a $10,000 fine for the distribution charge.Â  On the proximity charge, 
  Walton was sentenced to ten years in prison, suspended upon time served and 
  three years probation, and fined $10,000.Â  The court ordered the sentences to 
  run consecutively.Â  
On appeal, Walton contends for the first time that 
  the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to accept his guilty plea 
  to distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a school because the indictment 
  described the nearby school as the â€œYork Adult Education Center.â€ Walton asserts 
  the center is not a type of school specifically included in the applicable statute.
A circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction 
  to convict a defendant of a criminal offense if (1) there has been an indictment 
  that sufficiently states the offense, (2) there has been a written waiver of 
  presentment, or (3) the charge is a lesser-included offense of the crime charged 
  in the indictment.Â  Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 580 S.E.2d 120 (2003).Â  
  The lack of subject-matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time and can be 
  raised sua sponte by the court.Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 572 
  S.E.2d 309 (Ct. App. 2002).
Section 44-53-445 provides that it shall 
  be unlawful to distribute a controlled substance â€œwithin a one-half mile radius 
  of the grounds of a public or private elementary, middle, or secondary school; 
  a public playground or park; a public vocational or trade school or technical 
  educational center; or a public or private college or university.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 44-53-445(A) (2002).
In this case, the indictment for the proximity 
  charge alleged Walton distributed â€œa controlled substance, to wit:Â  crack cocaine, 
  within a one-half mile radius of the grounds of York Adult Education Center, 
  a public school located in the city of York, South Carolina, . . . in 
  violation of Section 44-53-445, Code of Laws of South Carolina (1976), as 
  amended.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  
Walton argues the indictment is fatally 
  flawed because the York Adult Education Center is not specifically included 
  among the types of qualifying schools listed in the statute, citing Brown 
  v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 540 S.E.2d 846 (2001).Â  In Brown, the indictment 
  alleged that the distribution occurred within proximity of a day-care center.Â  
  Our supreme court found the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to accept the defendantâ€™s guilty plea because day-care centers were not specifically 
  included among the types of schools listed in the statute.Â  
In the current appeal, the indictment alleges the 
  distribution of crack cocaine occurred within a half-mile radius of a public 
  school in violation of section 44-53-445, and names the institution, â€œYork Adult 
  Education Center.â€Â  
Although the indictment alleges the institution 
  is a â€œpublic school,â€ it does not otherwise specify whether it is a secondary 
  school or a vocational, trade, or technical school, all of which are qualifying 
  institutions under the statute.Â  See Brown, 343 S.C. at 349, 540 
  S.E.2d at 850 (stating â€œsection 44-53-445 does not simply criminalize distribution 
  within proximity of a â€˜school,â€™ but instead very specifically lists the 
  types of schools coveredâ€).Â  In State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 
  745 (2001), however, our supreme court held that â€œ[w]hile the better practice 
  is to set forth the elements of the crime in the indictment rather than referring 
  to the statutory section alleged to have been violated,â€ an indictment was sufficient 
  to provide the defendant with notice of the elements of the offense where it 
  referenced the appropriate statute.Â  Id. at 649, 552 S.E.2d at 751.Â  
  The indictment against Walton clearly alleges the distribution occurred within 
  a half-mile radius of a public school in violation of section 44-53-445; thus, 
  we find the indictment sufficiently gave Watkins notice that the distribution 
  allegedly occurred at a public school that was within the terms of the statute.Â  

We also hold Watkins waived any argument about 
  whether the indictment sufficiently stated the offense to confer jurisdiction 
  on the court since he signed a written waiver of presentment.Â  In Hooks v. 
  State, 353 S.C. 48, 577 S.E.2d 211 (2003), our supreme court noted as follows:Â  


Two exceptions apply to the general rule that an indictment 
  must sufficiently state the offense to confer jurisdiction on a court.Â  The 
  first applies if the defendant waives presentment.Â  The second applies where 
  the charge to which the defendant pleads guilty is a lesser-included offense 
  of the crime charged in the indictment.

Id. at 51 n.2, 577 S.E.2d at 213 n.2 (emphasis 
  added). 
AFFIRMED. [2] 
ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving the issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  Although our supreme court has had several cases raising the issue 
    of subject-matter jurisdiction in this context, we note that, in a case involving 
    the issue of a directed verdict, this court inferred that the question whether 
    or not the York Adult Education Center fell within the scope of the statute 
    was a question of fact for a jury to determine. Â State v. Chisolm, 
    355 S.C. 175, 584 S.E.2d 401 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied (Apr. 8, 
    2004), and overruled on other grounds by 
    State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 598 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The 
    question of whether or not the indictment conveyed subject-matter jurisdiction 
    was not addressed.Â

title: SC Department of Social Services v. Truitt
description: In this termination of parental rights action, the Court affirms the family court's finding that petitioners abandoned their children.
text:
SCDSS v. Truitt



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Michael Truitt, Sandra Ivester, John Doe, Defendants,
of whom Michael Truitt and Sandra Ivester are Appellants.
In the Interest of: Gabriel Truitt (DOB:Â  11-2-99),
Elijah 
  TruittÂ Â  (DOB:Â  11-2-99), and Alexis TruittÂ  (DOB:Â  12/11/00), Minors Under 
  the Age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3873
Heard September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed October 11, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
Katherine H. Tiffany and Tracy Welsh Tiddy,
both of Greenville, for Appellants.
Rebecca Rush Wray, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Carol Anne Simpson, of Greenville, for Guardian Ad Litem.
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Michael Truitt and 
  Sandra Ivester appeal the termination of their parental rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Sandra Ivester and Michael Truitt are the parents 
  of three childrenâ€”Gabriel, Elijah, and Alexis.Â  Although the two have been romantically 
  involved for eight years, they never married.Â  When this action commenced, Gabriel 
  and Elijah were eighteen months old and Alexis was six months old.Â  
On June 10, 2001, Sandra took the children to have 
  Sunday dinner at Michaelâ€™s parentsâ€™ house.Â  After dinner, while Sandra and her 
  children were napping, Michael borrowed Sandraâ€™s car and went to visit friends.Â  
  Later, he returned to the house and asked Sandra to accompany him as he dropped 
  off his friends.Â  Sandra agreed to go, left her children with their grandparents, 
  and told them she would be back in approximately fifteen minutes. 
  [1] Â  
Sandra and Michael did not return home in fifteen 
  minutes.Â  In fact, they had not returned by the next morning.Â  Because Michaelâ€™s 
  mother had to work and his father suffered from medical difficulties, neither 
  was able to care for the children. 
  [2] Â  Having tried to contact Sandra and Michael numerous times, the grandparents 
  were left with no option but to call the Department of Social Services (â€œDSSâ€).Â Â  
  Corporal Miller, of the Mauldin Police Department, testified that when he arrived 
  at the Truittâ€™s home on Monday he made further attempts to locate the childrenâ€™s 
  parents, but was unsuccessful.Â  Lacking proper supervision, the children were 
  taken into emergency protective custody.Â  
After Sandra and Michael left his parentâ€™s house 
  on Sunday, Michael allowed a couple of â€œfriendsâ€ to borrow Sandraâ€™s car in exchange 
  for $100.00 of crack cocaine.Â  While the car was gone, both parents smoked the 
  crack at another friendâ€™s apartment.Â  Neither parent attempted to contact the 
  grandparents until after DSS took custody of the children.Â  When they finally 
  did call Monday afternoon, they were informed that DSS removed the children.Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Sandra testified she did not return on Sunday to 
  pick up the children because Michaelâ€™s friends never brought back the car.Â  
  She also testified she did not call the grandparents because there was no telephone 
  in the apartment where they were staying.Â  Sandra explained that a number of 
  Mauldin police officers lived in the area, and she was afraid if she left the 
  apartment to find a telephone then she would be picked up on outstanding warrants.Â  

Even though both were fully aware DSS had their 
  children, for the next two months Sandra and Michael spent their time living 
  in motel rooms and smoking crack every other day.Â  They called Michaelâ€™s parents 
  from time to time to ask for money and talk about the children, but otherwise 
  did not attempt to contact their children or DSS despite testimony that they 
  knew the name of their caseworker.Â Â  The authorities did not locate Sandra and 
  Michael until they were arrested, living in a hotel, on August 14, 2001.Â Â Â  

Following their arrest, Sandra did not request 
  visitation with her children until the first week of October 2001.Â  She cancelled 
  the first scheduled visitation and did not actually meet with the children until 
  October 25, 2001, more than four months after the children were left with their 
  grandparents.Â  Michael never contacted DSS to seek visitation or to check on 
  the childrenâ€™s welfare.Â  Thus, DSS initiated this termination of parental rights 
  (â€œTPRâ€) action on July 26, 2001.Â  
At the time of the hearing, Sandra was released 
  from jail and working in a family catering business.Â  Although Michael was still 
  incarcerated, he expected to be released from custody at the end of 2003.Â  The 
  children were placed with a foster family who expressed interest in adopting 
  all three children.Â  
Significantly, this was not the first time DSS 
  became involved in the childrenâ€™s lives.Â  In October 2000, Michael left Gabriel 
  and Elijahâ€”then eleven months oldâ€”home alone while he went to purchase illegal 
  drugs.Â  Sandra was incarcerated at the time and unable to watch the children.Â  
  Accordingly, Gabriel and Elijah were taken into emergency protective custody.Â  
  DSS filed an action concerning this incident and an Order was issued on February 
  21, 2001, which made a â€œfinding of threat of harm of physical neglectâ€ against 
  Michael and ordered treatment plans for both parents.Â  The order granted custody 
  to Sandra, but only granted Michael supervised visitation.Â  Although Sandra 
  completed the treatment plans outlined in the order, Michael did not.Â  The third 
  child, Alexis, was born in December 2000; therefore, the previous court order 
  did not address custody or visitation rights as they pertained to her.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn a termination of parental rights 
  (TPR) case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€Â  
  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (citing South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 
  129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  Before a parentâ€™s rights may 
  be terminated, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and 
  convincing evidence.Â  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Mrs. H, 346 S.C. 329, 333, 
  550 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
On appeal, this court may review the record 
  and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported 
  by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.; see also South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 
  506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, despite this broad scope of review, this 
  court is not required to disregard the findings of the family court nor ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to evaluate the credibility 
  of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  This is especially true in cases involving the welfare of children.Â  
  Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilcox, 304 S.C. 90, 93, 403 S.E.2d 
  142, 144 (Ct. App. 1991).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Under South Carolinaâ€™s termination of parental 
  rights statute, â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights 
  upon a finding of one or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination 
  is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2003). 
  [3] Â  If the family court finds a statutory ground for termination has been 
  proven, it must then find the best interests of the children would be served 
  by termination.Â  Id.Â Â  Significantly, as our supreme court has noted 
  and the TPR statute provides: â€œTPR statutes â€˜must be liberally construed in 
  order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the 
  custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent[-]child relationship.â€™â€Â  
  Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 
  (2000) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 1999)).
In the current case, the family court determined 
  that Michael and Sandra abandoned their three children.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(7) (Supp. 2003).Â  As an alternative ground, the court ruled 
  that Michaelâ€™s rights should also be terminated because of harm inflicted on 
  the children pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1) (Supp. 2003). [4] Â  After finding statutory grounds for termination, 
  the family court determined it would be in the childrenâ€™s best interest for 
  Sandra and Michaelâ€™s parental rights to be terminated.Â  
  1.     Abandonment  
The family court found that Michael and Sandra 
  abandoned their three children.Â  We agree.
Section 20-7-1572(7) of the South Carolina Code 
  (Supp. 2003) provides in pertinent part, that a family court may order the termination 
  of parental rights upon a finding of abandonment.Â  Section 20-7-490(19) defines 
  abandonment as occurring when â€œa parent or guardian wilfully deserts a child 
  or wilfully surrenders physical possession of a child without making adequate 
  arrangements for the childâ€™s needs or the continuing care of the child.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490 (Supp. 2003).Â  The willful standard for termination has 
  been explained as â€œa question of intent to be determined from the facts and 
  circumstances of each individual case.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. 
  v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 610, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  Furthermore, 
  parental conduct â€œwhich evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties 
  may fairly be characterized as â€˜willfulâ€™ because it manifests a conscious indifference 
  to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 
  835, 839 (1992). 
We do not think the family court erred in deciding 
  that Michael and Sandraâ€™s actions constituted a willful intent to abandon.Â  
  As noted previously, both Michael and Sandra were aware the grandparents were 
  unable to care for the children for extended periods of time.Â Â Â  Michaelâ€™s mother 
  specifically told them she was leaving Sunday evening for an engagement, both 
  knew she had to work the next day, and both knew that Mr. Truitt was unable 
  to care for the children.Â  Despite this knowledge, neither made an effort to 
  return to the Truittsâ€™ and resume care of their children.Â  Although the parents 
  assert they did not have access to a car, both must admit it was their decision 
  to trade the use of the car for drugs.Â  The fact that the carâ€™s borrowers did 
  not promptly return the car does not serve to mitigate the parentsâ€™ failure 
  to find a way home to their children.Â  
The parents also argue that they did not call to 
  check on their children or ask the grandparents for a ride home because the 
  apartment they were staying in did not have a telephone and they feared being 
  arrested if they left the apartment.Â  The mother appears to be saying that by 
  not taking the risk of being arrested on outstanding warrants she was watching 
  out for her childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  This argument, however, is incomprehensible.Â  
  She knew the grandparents could not provide for her children for an extended 
  period of time and she promised to be back in fifteen minutes for this reason.Â  
  Clearly, Sandra broke this promise by embarking on a course of illegal behavior 
  that would necessarily take longer than fifteen minutes.Â  
When the parents finally did call and were told the 
  children had been taken into emergency protective custody, neither made an effort 
  to contact DSS in an attempt to regain custody or at the very least to check 
  on their childrenâ€™s welfare.Â  Instead, the parents proceeded to spend the next 
  two months living in hotel rooms and using crack cocaine every other day.Â  In 
  fact, the only thing that prevented the parents from continuing this course 
  of behavior was their arrest on August 14, 2001.Â  Prior to the arrest, the parentsâ€™ 
  concern with their children was limited to an occasional call to the grandparents.
Michael argues that because a previous court order 
  granted legal custody of two of their children to Sandra, it was not possible 
  for him to abandon them.Â  We are unconvinced by this argument.Â  Michael did 
  have access to the children and he testified that he saw them everyday.Â  While 
  Michael did not have legal custody of the children, he did have the right to 
  supervised visitation even though he did not pursue this right.Â  In fact, he 
  did not make any effort whatsoever to contact his children from the time they 
  were abandoned on June 10, 2001, until his rights were terminated on November 
  28, 2001.Â  Furthermore, this absence was the result of his decisions, which 
  placed his desires and needs above those of his children.Â  See Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs. v. Henry, 296 S.C. 507, 509, 374 S.E.2d 298, 299-300 (1988) 
  (finding â€œvoluntary pursuit of a course of lawlessness resulting in imprisonment, 
  coupled with [the parentâ€™s] flagrant indifference towards the children during 
  intervening periods of freedom, manifest[ed] . . . abandonmentâ€).Â  In addition 
  to removing himself from his childrenâ€™s lives, he encouraged Sandra to abandon 
  them as well.Â  Michaelâ€™s actions do not show concern and attention for his childrenâ€™s 
  welfare; rather, they reflect a conscious indifference to the same.
Although the family court also 
  found Michaelâ€™s parental rights should be terminated pursuant to section 20-7-1572(1) 
  of the South Carolina Code, (Supp. 2003), because we find the trial court was 
  correct in concluding the children were abandoned, we need not address this 
  aspect of the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  See Rule 220 (c), SCACR; Futch v. McAllister 
  Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) 
  (appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior 
  issue is dispositive).
  2.     Best Interests of the Children  
In addition to finding Michael and Sandra abandoned 
  their children, the family court concluded that termination of their parental 
  rights would be in the childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  We agree.
Governmental intervention in a parent-child relationship 
  is of great moment and concern.Â  The United States Supreme Court has held that 
  â€œa parentâ€™s desire for and right to â€˜the companionship, care, custody and management 
  of his or her childrenâ€™ is an important interest that â€˜undeniably warrants deference 
  and, absent a powerful countervailing interest, protection.â€™â€Â  Lassiter v. 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. of Durham County, N.C., 452 U.S. 18, 27 (1981) (quoting 
  Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645, 651 (1972)).Â  Societyâ€™s fundamental 
  relational basis is the family, and a government is wise that respects its importance.Â  
  See M.L.B. v. S.L.J., 519 U.S. 102, 116 (1996) (â€œChoices about 
  marriage, family life, and the upbringing of children are among associational 
  rights this Court has ranked as â€˜of basic importance in our society,â€™ rights 
  sheltered by the Fourteenth Amendment against the Stateâ€™s unwarranted usurpation, 
  disregard, or disrespect.â€) (citation omitted).Â  However, the primary goal must 
  be to protect the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 
  S.C. 281, 295, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).Â  
In this case, reversing the family court would 
  return the children to a father who repeatedly deserted his children to fulfill 
  his drug addiction, failed to fulfill his obligations under a previous court 
  order, and encouraged the mother to desert her children.Â  It would also return 
  the children to a mother who deserted her children for more than four months, 
  and has a drug addiction, a criminal history, and remained in a relationship 
  with a father who previously neglected their children.Â  To affirm the decision 
  is to free the children from the bonds of foster care and allow them the opportunity 
  to be adopted into a stable and nurturing home.Â Â Â  
Although the preference of the law is to return 
  children to their parents, the presumption that a natural parent is a fit parent 
  must be balanced against reality.Â  See Troxel v. Granville, 530 
  U.S. 57, 69 (2000) (noting the traditional presumption that a fit 
  parent will act in the best interests of a child) (emphasis added).Â  The United 
  States Supreme Court has stated that â€œso long as a parent adequately cares for 
  his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no reason 
  for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family . . . .â€Â  
  Id. at 68 (citation omitted).Â  In this case, Sandra and Michael failed 
  to care for their children.Â  The reality we confront today is of a mother and 
  father who have demonstrated a gross indifference to the welfare of their children.Â  
  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Ledford, 357 S.C. 371, 
  377, 593 S.E.2d 175, 177 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œa parentâ€™s responsibility extends 
  beyond making initial arrangements for his or her child while the parent is 
  away; the statute requires that the parent make adequate arrangements for the 
  childâ€™s continuing care.â€).Â  As such, we find it is in the childrenâ€™s 
  best interest to terminate Michael and Sandraâ€™s parental rights. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we find the family 
  court did not err in ruling Michael and Sandra abandoned the children.Â  We also 
  agree with the family court that termination of their parental rights is in 
  the childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
  [5] 
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Michaelâ€™s mother, Sally Truitt, testified that she told the childrenâ€™s 
    parents she had an engagement later that night, and both said they â€œwould 
    be back.â€Â  

 
   
    [2]  Sandra testified that she was aware of the circumstances and knew 
    Michaelâ€™s parents were unable to care for the children for an extended period 
    of time.Â  

 
   
    [3]  Section 20-7-1572 was recently amended to include an additional ground 
    for termination; however, this amendment has no applicability in the current 
    case.Â  See Act No. 181, 2004 S.C. Acts 1829.

 
   
    [4]  Section 20-7-1572(1) of the South Carolina Code provides that a family 
    court may terminate parental rights when:
  
  The child or another child in the home has been harmed as 
    defined in Section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of 
    the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made 
    safe within twelve months.Â  In determining the likelihood that the home can 
    be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another 
    child in the home may be considered[.]â€Â  
  
  Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  

 
   
    [5]  This court would also like to acknowledge and commend defense counsel 
    for the thorough and zealous representation of their court appointed clients.Â  
    As the late Judge Bell once noted, such representation is â€œin the best tradition 
    of the legal profession.â€Â  Leone v. Dilullo, 294 S.C. 410, 414, 365 
    S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 1988).Â Â

title: Loftis v. SCE&G
description: In this review of a grant of summary judgment, this court concludes that the undisputed evidence before the master-in-equity supports his establishment of an easement by prescription on the part of SCE&G.
text:
Loftis v. SCE&G


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James M. Loftis and Roxana T. Loftis, Appellants,
v.
South Carolina Electric and Gas Company, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3874
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 11, 2004Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth C. Krawcheck, of Charleston, for Appellant.
John M. Mahon, Jr. and Beaumont Barre Covert, both of Columbia; 
  Wade H. Logan, III, Elizabeth Scott Moise and M. Scott Taylor, all of Charleston, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Â In this action filed by a 
  property owner seeking an injunction preventing SCE&G from maintaining power 
  lines on his property and damages resulting from past maintenance, the owner 
  challenges the masterâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  The master based his ruling 
  on, among other things, SCE&Gâ€™s establishment of a prescriptive easement 
  to maintain the power lines. We affirm.
FACTS
On September 4, 1998, James and Roxana 
  Loftis (â€œAppellantsâ€) purchased a parcel of land located on Bryan Road in Hollywood, 
  South Carolina.Â  On two occasions prior to purchasing the property, Mr. Loftis 
  conducted a walking inspection of the land.Â  Two power lines extended across 
  the property, one dedicated to the previous ownerâ€™s residence and a second line 
  that provided electrical service to all the residents of Bryan road.Â Â Â  
While inspecting the property at the request of 
  Mr. Loftis for the purpose of initiating basic electrical service, SCE&G 
  determined that safety concerns mandated routine trimming around all the power 
  lines on the property.Â  Thus, on three occasions, SCE&Gâ€™s independent contractors 
  entered the property to clear vegetation.Â  On two occasions, Appellantsâ€™ father, 
  who was staying on the property, halted the trimming.Â  
Believing SCE&Gâ€™s trimming activities damaged 
  their property, Appellants brought suit, asserting claims of conversion, negligence, 
  and trespass.Â  Appellants asked the court for money damages, an order requiring 
  SCE&G to remove the existing power lines, and an injunction preventing SCE&G 
  from entering the property in the future.Â  
On October 4, 2002, SCE&G filed and served 
  a motion for summary judgment on all causes of action.Â  On the day scheduled 
  for trial, the master agreed to hear arguments on SCE&Gâ€™s summary judgment 
  motion prior to the start of trial.Â  Indicating he felt â€œhamstrung,â€ Appellantsâ€™ 
  trial attorney explained he was surprised a hearing was being held on the motion.Â  
  The master postponed the trial, allowing Appellants â€œten days to submit a Brief 
  with any supporting affidavits, or evidence that you want.â€Â  After reviewing 
  supplemental material from both parties, the master granted summary judgment 
  on the trespass and conversion causes of action based on multiple grounds.Â  
  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to 
  expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact 
  finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); 
  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  When 
  reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same 
  standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Fleming v. 
  Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  Summary judgment is 
  proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving 
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Laurens Emergency Med. 
  Specialists v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 108, 584 S.E.2d 
  375, 377 (2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the 
  evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light 
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Public Serv. Auth., 
  354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).Â  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 
  353 S.C. 449, 455-56, 578 S.E.2d 711, 714 (2003).Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
Appellants first argue the trial court 
  erred in hearing SCE&Gâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the day trial was 
  scheduled to begin.Â  In support of their position they cite Rule 6(d), SCRCP, 
  which reads, â€œa written motion . . . and notice of the hearing thereof, shall 
  be served not later than ten days before the time specified for the hearing.â€Â  

We conclude there was no reversible error 
  in the procedure followed by the trial court.Â  SCE&Gâ€™s motion was filed 
  and served twenty-seven days before the hearing.Â  In response to objections 
  to the timing of the motion hearing, the trial court granted Appellants ten 
  additional days to submit a brief and opposing affidavits and did not rule on 
  the motion until full consideration of these materials was given.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find Appellants have not been prejudiced.Â  See Dedes v. Strickland, 
  307 S.C. 152, 155, 414 S.E.2d 132, 134 (1992) (holding that failure to give 
  written notice of a motion hearing is reversible error when it â€œwrongfully denie[s] 
  the opportunity to submit affidavits, documents or testimony opposing . . . 
  the motionâ€ and thereby causes prejudice to the opposing party).Â  Having addressed 
  Appellantsâ€™ procedural exception, we move now to the merits of the masterâ€™s 
  findings.Â  
The master concluded, as one of several 
  grounds for finding a valid easement on Appellantsâ€™ property, that SCE&G 
  successfully established an easement by prescription.Â  We affirm the masterâ€™s 
  decision on this ground. [1]   
In order to establish an easement by prescription 
  a party must show: (1) the continued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of a 
  right for a full period of twenty years; (2) the identity of the thing enjoyed; 
  and (3) that the use or enjoyment was adverse or under claim of right.Â  Horry 
  County v. Laychur, 315 S.C. 364, 367, 434 S.E.2d 259, 261 (1993); Babb 
  v. Harrison, 220 S.C. 20, 24-25, 66 S.E.2d 457, 458 (1951); Hartley v. 
  John Wesley United Methodist Church of Johns Island, 355 S.C. 145, 150, 
  584 S.E.2d 386, 388 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Having reviewed the elements which define 
  a prescriptive easement, we now review the evidence on the matter, being mindful 
  to give Appellants â€œthe benefit of all favorable inferences that might reasonably 
  be drawn therefrom.â€ Estes v. Roper Temporary Services, 304 S.C. 120, 
  121, 403 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1991). 
We find ample undisputed evidence in the 
  record to support the masterâ€™s finding of a prescriptive easement.Â  An agent 
  of SCE&G testified that he inspected several telephone poles supporting 
  the electrical lines crossing Appellantsâ€™ property and found a â€œbirthmarkâ€ on 
  one pole reading 1972 and another reading 1954. [2] Â  The son of Appellantsâ€™ propertyâ€™s 
  prior owner, who is also a current neighbor of Appellants, testified that the 
  property in question has received electrical service through the power lines 
  since at least 1949.Â  A life-time neighbor and family friend to the propertyâ€™s 
  prior owners testified that the power lines at issue have been on the property 
  since the 1930â€™s, and electrical service provided every decade since.Â  Because 
  one of the two power lines in question is a â€œprimary distribution lineâ€ that 
  supplies power to the rest of Bryan Road, the few intermittent periods where 
  Appellantsâ€™ property did not receive electrical service do not cause the prescriptive 
  easement to fail for lack of â€œcontinualâ€ or â€œuninterruptedâ€ use.Â  Even when 
  Appellantsâ€™ property was without electrical service, the power lines were still 
  being maintained and used by SCE&G.Â  The evidence clearly supports the masterâ€™s 
  conclusion that SCE&G used the property to supply power to the residents 
  of Bryan Road for the required twenty-year period. 
The brunt of Appellantsâ€™ argument, however, 
  lies in the third requirement for establishing an easement by prescription.Â  
  Appellants incorrectly assert that a prescriptive easement cannot be established 
  in this case because â€œ[o]bviously, use is not adverse where the [d]efendant 
  had a mistaken belief it had the right to be on the property.â€Â  Appellants ignore 
  that a prescriptive easement can also be established under a â€œclaim of right,â€ 
  or, in other words, under the very mistaken belief Appellants admit drove SCE&Gâ€™s 
  actions.Â  Our courts have held that a party may earn a prescriptive easement 
  under a claim of right if â€œhe demonstrate[s] a substantial belief that he had 
  the right to useâ€ the property in a manner consistent with the alleged easement.Â  
  Hartley, 355 S.C. at 151, 584 S.E.2d at 389; see also Revis, 
  321 S.C. at 209, 467 S.E.2d at 462 (holding a partyâ€™s belief about her right 
  to use a road flowed from a claim of right); Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 
  522, 528, 492 S.E.2d 420, 424 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting a partyâ€™s belief that 
  he had a right-of-way may be sufficient for a prescriptive easement pursuant 
  to a claim of right).Â  
In the case before us, SCE&G has used 
  and maintained the power lines in question since the 1930â€™s pursuant to their 
  belief they had a valid right-of-way to use the property in this manner.Â Â  Evidence 
  supporting this belief, or claim of right, was presented to the master in the 
  form of testimony regarding SCE&Gâ€™s search for documents, believed to exist 
  but missing, proving a filed right-of-way on the property.Â  Furthermore, SCE&G 
  presented as evidence several versions of their general service terms and conditions, 
  which have stated the following since 1962:

â€œThe Customer, in requesting or accepting service, thereby 
  grants the Company without charge necessary rights-of-way and trimming and clearing 
  privileges for its facilities along, across, and under property controlled by 
  the Customer . . . to the extent that such rights-of-way and trimmings are required 
  or necessary to enable Company to supply service to the CustomerÂ  . . . [and] 
  to serve other Customers.â€

Since the prior owners of Appellantsâ€™ property requested 
  and received decades of electrical service, this evidence clearly supports the 
  masterâ€™s finding that SCE&G had a substantial belief it had a right to use 
  the property in the manner it did based upon the totality of the circumstances.Â  
  Pursuant to this Courtâ€™s standard of review, we therefore uphold the masterâ€™s 
  establishment of an easement by prescription in favor of SCE&G.
Finally, we address Appellantsâ€™ contention 
  that since they never requested electrical service from SCE&G, [3]  they are not bound by SCE&Gâ€™s easement 
  on the property, no matter what theory supports the easementâ€™s establishment.Â  
  A purchaser of land with actual, constructive, or implied notice that the property 
  is burdened with an easement ordinarily takes the estate subject to the easement.Â  
  25 Am Jur 2d Easements and Licenses Â§ 106 at 677 (1996).Â  In order to 
  charge the purchaser of a servient estate with notice of an unrecorded easement, 
  the marks of the servitude must be open and visible.Â  25 Am Jur 2d Easements 
  and Licenses Â§ 107 at 678 (1996).Â  Here, the marks of the easement (the 
  poles and power lines) were open and visible.Â  Furthermore, Appellants admit 
  to making inspections of the property and to actual knowledge of the power lines 
  prior to the propertyâ€™s purchase.Â  We therefore conclude that Appellants purchased 
  the property subject to SCE&Gâ€™s prescriptive easement.
For the foregoing reasons, the master-in-equityâ€™s 
  decision is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1] Â Â  In light of our disposition of the case on the issue of prescriptive 
    easement, it is not necessary to address Appellantsâ€™ remaining issues.Â  See 
    Rule 220 (c), SCACR; Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 
    335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (appellate courts need not address 
    remaining issues when the disposition of a prior issue is dispositive).Â  

 
   
    [2] Â  A â€œbirthmarkâ€ is a physical marking SCE&G places on its telephone 
    poles which reflect the year in which they were erected. 

 
   [3]  Although Appellants did not officially request 
    electrical service prior to the trimming that gave rise to this action, they 
    have since requested and received such service.

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edwin W. Rowland, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
Janet F. Rodman, of Hilton Head Island, pro se, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 WILLIAMS, J.: John R. Rodman, Jr. 
  (â€œHusbandâ€) appeals a family court denial of his motion to vacate a previous 
  order, which, by the adoption of an agreement between Husband and Janet F. Rodman 
  (â€œWifeâ€), awarded Wife â€œreimbursement alimony.â€Â  Husband argues that, because 
  the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction, the judgment is void; therefore 
  the family court erred in denying the motion as time barred under Rule 60(b), 
  SCRCP. We disagree.
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Husband and Wife participated in a marriage 
  ceremony on August 19, 1999.Â  Husband, however, was not legally divorced from 
  his prior spouse (his fifth wife) until August 31, 1999.Â  In September 2001, 
  Wife discovered Husband was still married to another woman on the date of their 
  marriage. [1] Â  Since this discovery, 
  the parties have lived separate and apart from one another.
In November 2001, the parties, voluntarily 
  and with ample opportunity to seek the advice of counsel, entered into a written 
  settlement agreement.Â  Although not officially represented by counsel until 
  later, Husband was aided during the agreement negotiations by an attorney and 
  family friend, who helped him draft some documents.Â  The parties agreed in writing, 
  inter alia, to the following:

1.Â  Husband was not legally divorced from his previous wife 
  at the time of their marriage; thus, an annulment was appropriate. 
2. The written agreement constituted â€œa final permanent settlement 
  between them with respect to the division of all their property, both real and 
  personal, and with respect to any and all rights of support and all other rights 
  and obligations.â€Â  
3. The agreement â€œis not conditioned upon the obtaining of 
  divorce, but instead is intended to be a complete and full settlement between 
  the parties independent of the obtaining of a divorce.â€Â  

Under the heading â€œALIMONY/INSURANCE,â€ 
  Wife agreed to accept $150,460 payable in 120 monthly increments of $2,158, 
  as â€œreimbursement alimonyâ€ for debt Husband allegedly accrued in her name during 
  their marriage.Â  These payments are addressed again in the agreement, under 
  the heading â€œDIVISION OF PERSONAL DEBT,â€ as follows:

The parties agree that Wife shall pay debt in her name, 
  however she is depending on the Spousal support payment from Husband to make 
  all the payments.Â  Husband must pay Wife her alimony in a timely fashion so 
  that she can pay the debt he incurred during the marriage.

On March 1, 2002, the family court granted Wife 
  a decree of separate support and maintenance, 
  [2]  which fully incorporated the written agreement. Although properly served 
  with the summons, complaint, and notice of the final hearing, Husband did not 
  attend the hearing which led to this family court order.Â  
On March 28, 2003, more than one year following 
  the order, Husband filed a motion to vacate the family courtâ€™s decree of separate 
  support and maintenance on the ground that the marriage was void ab initio 
  and, as a result, any agreement entered into regarding alimony is null and void.Â  
  Pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, the family court denied Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate 
  on the ground that it was filed more than one year after the date of the initial 
  order.Â  This appeal followed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court 
  has jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 
  244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  This court, however, is not required to disregard the 
  family courtâ€™s findings; nor should we ignore the fact that the family court 
  judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their testimony.Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 
  838 (Ct. App. 1999); Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 453, 486 S.E.2d 516, 
  519 (Ct. App. 1997).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred by denying 
  his motion as time barred under Rule 60(b), SCRCP. Husband bases this argument 
  on the proposition that the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to adopt the property agreement; thus, the judgment was void.Â  We disagree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, reads:

On motion . . . the court may relieve a party . . . from 
  a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:Â  (1) mistake, 
  inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect; (2) newly discovered evidence 
  . . . ; (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct . . . ; (4) the judgment 
  is void;Â  (5) the judgment has been satisfied . . . . 

The rule continues, â€œ[t]he motion shall be made within a 
  reasonable time, and for reasons (1), (2), and (3) not more than one year after 
  the judgment or proceeding was entered or taken.â€Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
It is undisputed that Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate 
  was filed more than one year following the entry of the family courtâ€™s order; 
  thus, to be considered timely under the rule, the motion must be based on either 
  subsection (4) or (5).Â  Because Husband makes no claim that the judgment has 
  been satisfied, the sole issue before this court is whether the family court 
  order is â€œvoidâ€ under the rule. See Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP.
The definition of â€œvoidâ€ under Rule 60(b) â€œonly 
  encompasses judgments from courts which failed to provide proper due process, 
  or judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction or personal 
  jurisdiction.â€Â  McDaniel v. U.S. Fid. and Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 
  478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Husband argues the family court erred 
  in applying the one-year deadline to his motion because the family court lacks 
  subject matter jurisdiction to adopt a property agreement incident a marriage 
  that was void ab initio. 
  [3] Â  He contends that, because of this alleged lack of subject matter jurisdiction, 
  the family court order is void, thus the family court should have applied the 
  â€œreasonable timeâ€ standard of Rule 60(b)(4), and not the one-year limit of subsection 
  (1), (2), and (3).Â  
Because the property agreement was adopted by 
  the family court in response to Wifeâ€™s petition for annulment and decree of 
  separate support and maintenance, we find Husbandâ€™s argument to be without merit.Â  
  It has long been established that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(6) (1976 & Supp. 
  2003) grants the family court exclusive jurisdiction over annulment proceedings.Â  
  White v. White, 283 S.C. 348, 349, 323 S.E.2d 521, 522 (1984).Â  Furthermore, 
  this jurisdiction extends, not just to the issue of the actual annulment, but 
  to â€œall matters in an annulment action, as in a divorce proceeding,â€ including 
  the equitable distribution of property.Â  Id., 283 S.C. at 350, 323 S.E.2d 
  at 522; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(30) (1976 & Supp. 
  2003) (granting the family court exclusive jurisdiction â€œto hear and determine 
  any questions of support, custody, separation, or any other matter over which 
  the court has jurisdiction.â€).
There is no legal distinction between a marriage 
  which is annulled and one terminated by reason of bigamy, as they are both void 
  ab intio, or â€œfrom the inception.â€Â  Splawn v. Splawn, 311 
  S.C. 423, 425, 429 S.E.2d 805, 806 (1993).Â  In fact, the South Carolina Supreme 
  Court has specifically held the family court has subject matter jurisdiction 
  to equitably distribute property in a bigamous marriage.Â  Id., 311 S.C. 
  at 424, 429 S.E.2d at 806.Â  Following the analysis of White and Splawn, 
  we find the family court had subject matter jurisdiction to adopt the agreement 
  of the parties.Â  Because the family court had subject matter jurisdiction to 
  decide the matter, Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate the order was untimely under Rule 
  60(b), SCRCP.
CONCLUSION
Because Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate was 
  untimely, the family court properly denied the motion.Â  The decision of the 
  family court is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Husband claims he told Wife about this inadvertent mistake immediately 
    upon realizing it himself.Â  Wife claims she discovered a record of the final 
    divorce date in a stack of Husbandâ€™s papers and Husband became verbally and 
    physically abusive when confronted with the evidence. 

 
   [2] Â  
   In what appears to be nothing more than a simple mistake, the decree of 
    separate support and maintenance is referenced once in the order as a â€œfinal 
    order of divorce.â€Â  

 
   
    [3]  Husband makes no allegation that the family court lacked personal 
    jurisdiction or failed to provide proper due process.

title: Hamilton v. R & L Transfer, Inc.
description: Reverses grant of directed verdict on liability and remands for a new trial upon finding that issues of negligence and proximate cause should, in this case, be decided by the jury.
text:
Hamilton v. R & L Transfer


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Melissa D. Hamilton a/k/a Melissa Dawn Hamilton,
Respondent,
v.
R & L Transfer, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3876
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed October 18, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED 
  


  
    
      
William A. Bryan, Jr. and Christian 
  Stegmaier, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Edward C. Boggs and S. Murry Kinard, both of Lexington, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Melissa D. Hamilton brought 
  this action against R & L Transfer, Inc., alleging the negligence 
  of an R & L Transfer employee caused a collision resulting in her injuries.Â  
  The trial judge directed a verdict for Hamilton on liability, and the jury awarded 
  damages to her.Â  R & L appeals.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and 
  remand.
FACTS
This action arises out of an automobile 
  accident that occurred in Lexington County on the morning of February 24, 1999. 
  Â Hamilton was driving to work on Interstate 20, traveling towards Columbia.Â  
  It was snowing and the snow was beginning to accumulate on the road.Â  Hamilton 
  crossed over an icy bridge, causing her to lose control of her vehicle and slide 
  into the median.Â  After her car stopped in the median, Hamilton got out of her 
  car and walked over to another disabled motorist in the median who had also 
  lost control of his vehicle.Â  As Hamilton walked over to the other vehicle in 
  the median, a car driven by Kim Wright also lost control while crossing the 
  icy bridge.Â  Wrightâ€™s vehicle made a 360-degree spin in the left-hand lane but 
  remained on the highway.Â  
Daniel G. Bishop, an employee with R & L Transfer, 
  was driving an eighteen-wheeler and traveling behind Wright.Â  Bishop crossed 
  over the ice-covered bridge without losing control.Â  However, as he crossed 
  over the bridge, Bishop saw Wright lose control of her vehicle.Â  Bishop testified 
  he had approximately one second to react when he first noticed Wrightâ€™s car 
  out of control.Â  Attempting to avoid a collision with Wrightâ€™s vehicle, Bishop 
  slowed and hugged the yellow line closest to the median.Â  However, Bishop and 
  Wright collided, forcing Bishop to veer the eighteen-wheeler into the median 
  where Hamilton stood outside her stranded vehicle.Â  Although Bishop was not 
  aware of a collision between his truck and Hamiltonâ€™s vehicle, his truck hit 
  Hamiltonâ€™s car, causing her car to leave the ground and land on her left leg, 
  pinning her underneath the car for several minutes.Â  Hamilton did not suffer 
  any broken bones, but did sustain muscle injury and missed a week and a half 
  of work.Â  
Hamilton brought this action against R & L 
  Transfer alleging Bishop negligently collided with her car.Â  R & L Transfer 
  answered and filed a third-party complaint for equitable indemnification and 
  negligence against Wright.Â  The circuit court granted Wrightâ€™s motion to dismiss 
  the third-party complaint.Â  R & L Transfer made a motion for summary judgment 
  which was denied.Â  At the conclusion of Hamiltonâ€™s case, R & L Transfer 
  sought a directed verdict, which was denied.Â  At the close of R & L Transferâ€™s 
  case, Hamilton moved for a directed verdict on the issue of liability.Â  The 
  trial judge granted the motion and submitted the issue of damages to the jury.Â  
  The jury awarded Hamilton $30,000 in actual damages and $20,000 in punitive 
  damages.Â  Hamilton was also awarded court costs.Â  
R & L Transfer filed motions for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict, a new trial based on the thirteenth juror doctrine, new trial absolute, 
  new trial nisi remittitur, and new trial based on prejudicial remarks by the 
  trial court.Â  The trial court denied each motion.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
R & L Transfer argues the trial court erred 
  in granting a directed verdict in Hamiltonâ€™s favor on the issue of liability.Â  
  We agree. 
We find the trial court erred in granting Hamiltonâ€™s 
  motion for a directed verdict because the issue of R & L Transferâ€™s negligence 
  was an issue for the jury.Â  When ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the 
  court is required to view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the 
  light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing 
  of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 611, 518 S.E.2d 591, 597 (1999).Â  â€œIf 
  more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the case 
  must be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Mullinax v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 
  333 S.C. 89, 92, 508 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1998).Â  
In order to prove R & L Transferâ€™s negligence, 
  it was essential for Hamilton to establish the following: (1) a duty of care 
  owed by R & L Transfer to Hamilton, (2) breach of that duty, and (3) damages 
  to Hamilton proximately resulting from the breach.Â  Thomasko v. Poole, 
  349 S.C. 7, 11, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002).Â  A partyâ€™s negligence is the proximate 
  cause only when, without the negligence, the injury could have been avoided 
  or would not have happened.Â  Alston v. Blue Ridge Transfer Co., 308 S.C. 
  292, 296, 417 S.E.2d 631, 633 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œIt is generally for the jury 
  to determine whether the defendantâ€™s negligence was a concurring proximate cause 
  of the plaintiffâ€™s injuries.Â  Only when the evidence is susceptible of only 
  one inference does proximate cause become a matter of law for the court.â€Â  Bishop 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 89, 502 S.E.2d 78, 
  83 (1998) (internal citation omitted).Â  
Although the evidence here indicates Bishopâ€™s vehicle 
  hit Hamiltonâ€™s, the evidence does not establish he breached his duty of due 
  care to Hamilton.Â  Because Hamilton was conversing with the other stranded motorist 
  in the median at the time Bishop crossed the bridge, Hamilton was unable to 
  offer any testimony regarding Bishopâ€™s speed or other characteristics of his 
  driving at the time of the accident.Â  Similarly, although Wright testified she 
  observed Bishop traveling at a higher rate of speed than the other vehicles 
  on the road, she further explained she only witnessed his driving before he 
  reached the overpass.Â  She did not see the R & L Transfer truck immediately 
  before the accident or as it occurred.Â  This evidence does not establish Bishop 
  was driving negligently at the time of the accident.Â  
Additionally, the evidence does not produce only the 
  inference Bishopâ€™s negligence, if any, was the proximate cause of Hamiltonâ€™s 
  damages.Â  Bishop testified he only had a second to react to the blocked roadway.Â  
  A neutral witness testified similarly. Â A jury could conclude either 
  the icy conditions or the sudden emergency of disabled and out-of-control vehicles 
  Bishop faced as he traversed the bridge caused the accident rather than negligent 
  driving by Bishop.Â  See Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 391-92, 
  529 S.E.2d 528, 540 (2000) (discussing the sudden emergency doctrine); Elrod 
  v. All, 243 S.C. 425, 438, 134 S.E.2d 410, 417 (1964) (noting the question 
  of sudden emergency is ordinarily for the jury).Â  Because the evidence here 
  is susceptible to more than one inference, the grant of Hamiltonâ€™s directed 
  verdict motion was error.Â  However, because we find R & L Transferâ€™s 
  liability was a jury issue, we affirm the denial of its directed verdict motion.Â  
  As a result of our reversal of Hamiltonâ€™s directed verdict, we further reverse 
  the award of court costs to Hamilton.
Having determined this
case should be remanded for a new trial, we do not address the remaining issues
on appeal. See Futch, 335 S.C. at 613, 518 S.E.2d at 598 (ruling appellate court need
not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive).
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
WILLIAMS, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.
