title: Mowrer v. Charleston County Park and Recreation Commission
description: This appeal concerns the grant of the directed verdict in an inverse condemnation action on the ground that the defendants lacked the authority to commit the acts on which the complaint was based.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Melvin H. Mowrer, Appellant,
v.
Charleston County Park and Recreation Commission and Charleston County,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3881
Heard September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed October 25, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Justin Oâ€™Toole Lucey, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Henry P. Wall, Warren C. Powell, Jr. and Joey R. Floyd, 
  of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Melvin H. Mowrer appeals a 
  directed verdict for the Charleston County Park and Recreation Commission and 
  Charleston County (collectively â€œDefendantsâ€) in his lawsuit arising from an 
  alleged inverse condemnation of his property.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Mowrer and his family own two adjacent properties located at 525 and 529 Mill 
  Street in the town of Mount Pleasant, South Carolina.Â  Mowrer and his wife purchased 
  525 Mill Street in 1987.Â  Their house is located at Shem Creek and overlooks 
  the marsh and water.Â  Mowrer owns 529 Mill Street with his brother.Â  

Both properties are located near the intersection 
  of Simmons and Mill Streets.Â  They are also close to Shem Creek Landing, 
  a boat ramp where boats on trailers are put into and pulled from Shem Creek.Â  
  Shem Creek Landing and a nearby parking lot are owned by the County and 
  leased to the Commission.
When the Mowrers purchased their home, Shem Creek 
  Landing was a small, simple boat ramp and unsuitable for large boats.Â  Both 
  Mill and Simmons were originally two-way streets.Â  Moreover, the Mowrers 
  could access Coleman Boulevard, a main thoroughfare, by driving from their driveway 
  directly onto Mill Street.
In 1992, the Commission approved a $34,000,000 
  bond issue for public works projects.Â  One of the projects, for which 
  $3,000,000 from the bond issue had been allocated, failed to go forward.Â  
  At the request of the Charleston County Council, the Commission took over 
  all the boat landings in the county, with the agreement that the previously 
  allocated $3,000,000 would be used on new boat ramps.Â  In addition, the 
  County provided an additional $200,000 to the Commission for this responsibility.
Prior studies had recommended closing Shem Creek 
  Landing because of its small size and deplorable condition.Â  The South 
  Carolina Department of Natural Resources and the Town of Mount Pleasant, however, 
  had already begun redesigning the landing before the Commission became involved.Â  
  The Commission eventually hired an engineer to design and reconfigure the 
  landing. 
The engineer submitted a number of landing designs 
  to the Commission.Â  Some plans included closing off Mill Street while 
  others did not.Â  Similarly, the plans varied as to whether Simmons Street 
  would remain a two-way street. 
The renovation plans chosen by the Commission initially 
  called for the condemnation of both Mowrer properties.Â  The Mowrers disagreed 
  with the Commissionâ€™s appraisal values and obtained second appraisals at the 
  Commissionâ€™s expense.Â  These appraisals assigned higher values to both properties.Â  
  Defendants opted not to pay the higher amounts and proceeded with the renovation 
  of the boat ramp by working around the Mowrer properties.Â  The project 
  was approved by the Town of Mount Pleasant and was completed in the late 
  1990s.Â  The parties stipulated that the Commission designed and constructed 
  the improvements and made the changes to the boat landing at Shem Creek.
As a result of the expansion of the boat ramp, 
  Simmons Street is used to queue up boaters for the landing.Â  This has resulted 
  in vehicles sometimes being parked in front of the Mowrersâ€™ driveway curb cuts, 
  thus restricting the Mowrersâ€™ access to their properties.Â  In addition, the 
  Mowrers cannot access Simmons Street from the front of their house because the 
  road has raised curbs that make it one-directional in the opposite way.Â  
  Also, a median built in connection with the project blocks the Mowrersâ€™ 
  direct access to Mill Street.Â  The Mowrersâ€™ driveways now terminate in 
  the boat landing itself, requiring them to go through the boat ramp parking 
  lot to access Mill Street. 
To reach Coleman Boulevard, the Mowrers must now 
  exit their driveway into the parking lot and turn right onto Scott Street before 
  finally making a left turn onto Mill Street.Â  If any boaters are backing 
  out while the Mowrers attempt to go through the parking lot, the Mowrers have 
  to wait for an opportunity to drive forward.Â  Compounding the problem 
  is the fact that one of the Mowrer properties has access to the street only 
  because the Mowrer family owns the adjacent lot. 
The enhanced landing now attracts more people with 
  larger boats.Â  In addition to traffic congestion, the increased use of 
  the boat ramp has resulted in more noise, fumes, and litter.Â  An appraiser 
  estimated that, because of the boat ramp expansion, the Mowrer properties lost 
  one third of their value.
Mowrer sued the Commission and the County, alleging 
  their actions constituted a taking, an inverse condemnation, and a nuisance. [1] Â  In their responsive pleadings, Defendants denied the allegations 
  of the complaint and raised additional defenses, including waiver, failure to 
  exhaust administrative remedies, and immunity from suit.
Mowrer later moved for partial summary judgment, 
  arguing the blocking of his access to Mill Street constituted a taking as a 
  matter of law.Â  On the day the trial was to begin, after a jury was drawn 
  but before presentation of the testimony, the trial court denied the motion.
At the conclusion of the testimony, the trial court 
  directed a verdict for Defendants.Â  The trial court also denied Mowrerâ€™s post-trial 
  motions.
1.Â  Mowrer 
  argues the trial court erred in directing a verdict for Defendants on his inverse 
  condemnation claim.Â  We agree.
Article I, Section 13 of the South Carolina Constitution 
  prohibits the taking of private property for public use without the payment 
  of just compensation. [2] Â  This 
  provision â€œextends to all cases in which any of the essential elements of ownership 
  has been destroyed or impaired as the result of the construction or maintenance 
  of a public street.â€ [3] Â  In 
  South Carolina, â€œan obstruction that materially injures or deprives the abutting 
  property owner of ingress or egress to and from his property is a â€˜takingâ€™ of 
  the property, for which recovery may be had.â€ 
  [4] Â  Moreover, â€œ[t]he fact that other means of access to the property are 
  available affects merely the amount of damages, and not the right of recovery.â€ [5] 
â€œThe elements of an inverse condemnation are (1) an affirmative, 
  positive, aggressive act on the part of the governmental agency, (2) a taking, 
  (3) the taking is for a public use, and (4) the taking has some degree of permanence.â€ 
  [6] Â  This court has recently held that the erection of a median barrier 
  could be an actionable interference with a constitutionally protected property 
  right of an abutting landowner. [7] 
  
In granting 
  the directed verdict, the trial court held Mowrer failed to prove that Defendants 
  had the authority to commit the acts on which his complaint was based. 
  [8] 
Although 
  there is authority that only a party with eminent domain power can be sued for 
  inverse condemnation, there is also authority to the contrary, i.e., that â€œ[a]s 
  long as the state acts through one of its arms in such a way as to deprive an 
  individual of his property for public use, it is irrelevant whether the state 
  arm doing the actual taking has eminent domain power.â€ [9] Â  
Case law 
  from this jurisdiction would seem to indicate that South Carolina follows the 
  latter view. [10] Â  Moreover, 
  we find persuasive the reasoning in Fountain v. Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid 
  Transit Authority, wherein the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals held that 
  â€œ[a]s long as the state acts through one of its arms in such a way as to deprive 
  an individual of his property for public use, it is irrelevant whether the state 
  arm doing the actual taking has eminent domain power.â€ [11] Â  In so holding, the court 
  gave the following explanation:

  If a private party were unable to seek redress under the just compensation 
    clause when an official agency acts outside its statutory powers and takes 
    property for public use, the state would be able to escape liability under 
    the just compensation clause by taking property through agencies without statutory 
    powers of eminent domain.Â  We think that the threat of this kind of shell 
    game ought to be avoided . . . . [12] 

Based on this reasoning, we hold that whether Defendants 
  had the authority to commit the acts about which Mowrer has complained is not 
  relevant to the question of whether these acts amounted to an unconstitutional 
  taking of his property for public use.Â  The fact that the Commission lacked 
  eminent domain power did not render its affirmative, positive, aggressive acts 
  concerning the Mowrer properties any less a taking within the meaning of Article 
  I, Section 13 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  It was therefore an error 
  of law to direct a verdict against Mowrer on the ground that he did not name 
  the Town as a defendant.
2.Â  Defendants argue that a directed verdict in 
  their favor should be affirmed because Mowrer failed to prove the elements of 
  inverse condemnation.Â  We decline to address this argument [13]  and note that, since the present case was 
  tried, there has been at least one appellate decision in this State that appears 
  relevant to this issue. [14] 
3.Â  We decline to address Mowrerâ€™s arguments that 
  he was entitled to an order of summary judgment and a directed verdict.Â  The 
  denial of summary judgment is not appealable, even after final judgment, [15]  and the record does not include 
  Mowrerâ€™s directed verdict motion. 
  [16] 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â  Both Mowrerâ€™s wife and brother executed assignments to Mowrer for 
    the prosecution of this action.

 
   
    [2] Â  See S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 13 (â€œExcept as otherwise provided 
    in this Constitution, private property shall not be taken . . . for public 
    use without just compensation being first made therefor.â€).

 
   
    [3] Â  Sease v. City of Spartanburg, 242 S.C. 520, 524-25, 131 S.E.2d 
    683, 685 (1963) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [4] Â  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t v. Allison, 246 S.C. 389, 
    393, 143 S.E.2d 800, 802 (1965); see also 29A C.J.S. Eminent Domain 
    Â§ 97, at 268 (1992) (â€œ[A]ny occupation or use of a street or highway for public 
    use which obstructs it so as to destroy or materially impair the easements 
    of an abutting owner is a taking of, or injury to, private property entitling 
    such owner to compensation, even though done by public authorization.â€).

 
   
    [5] Â  Allison, 246 S.C. at 393, 143 S.E.2d at 802.

 
   
    [6] Â  Gray v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 
    311 S.C. 144, 149, 427 S.E.2d 899, 902 (Ct. App. 1993).

 
   
    [7] Â  Hardin v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 359 S.C. 244, 
    249-54, 597 S.E.2d 814, 816-19 (Ct. App. 2004).

 
   [8] Â   
    The trial court appeared to rely on a tenet of the South Carolina Tort Claims 
    Act that liability is founded on acts that are within a governmental defendantâ€™s 
    scope of official duty.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-50(a) (Supp. 2003) 
    (â€œAny person who may suffer a loss proximately caused by a tort of the State, 
    an agency, a political subdivision, or a governmental entity, and its employee 
    acting within the scope of his official duty may file a claim as hereinafter 
    provided.â€).Â  This reliance was misplaced.Â  At issue here is not a tort 
    committed by the government against an individual but the taking by 
    the government of private property for public use without the payment of just 
    compensation.Â  Because the right to compensation for such a taking is a constitutional 
    right predating the Tort Claims Act, it cannot be altered by statute.Â  See, 
    e.g., Ins. Fin. Servs. v. S.C. Ins. Co., 282 S.C. 144, 147, 318 
    S.E.2d 10, 11 (1984) (holding an automobile insurerâ€™s contractual right to 
    terminate its agents was protected by the state and federal constitutions 
    and therefore could not be altered by subsequent statutory law).

 
   
    [9] Â  29A C.J.S. Eminent Domain Â§ 386, at 761 (1992).

 
   
    [10]  See South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t v. Moody, 267 
    S.C. 130, 136, 226 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1976) (holding a landowner whose property 
    was damaged by the government without having been condemned may bring an inverse 
    condemnation â€œagainst the contractor, or against the highway department, or 
    against the two, depending on the factsâ€).

 
   
    [11]  Fountain v. Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Auth., 678 
    F.2d 1038, 1043-44 (11th Cir. 1982).

 
   [12]  Id. at 1044.

 
   
    [13]  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 
    406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (stating an appellate court may not rely 
    on Rule 220(c), SCACR, to affirm a judgment â€œwhen the court believes it would 
    be unwise or unjust to do so in a particular caseâ€).Â  In a footnote, the supreme 
    court added that the appellate court â€œmay or may not wish to address [additional 
    sustaining] grounds when it reverses the lower courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  Id. 
    at 420 n.9, 526 S.E.2d at 723 n.9.

 
   
    [14]  See Hardin v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 359 
    S.C. 244, 597 S.E.2d 814 (Ct. App. 2004) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s determination 
    that the respondents were entitled to just compensation for the loss in value 
    of their properties caused by the closing of two roads at an intersection).

 
   
    [15]  Silverman v. Campbell, 326 S.C. 208, 211, 486 S.E.2d 1, 2 
    (1997).

 
   
    [16]  See Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 
    533 S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000) (noting the appellant has the burden of presenting 
    an adequate record on appeal).

description: In this employment scenario, the Court analyzes the following issues:  (1) did the written policies of Charleston County Parks and Recreation Commission alter the Appellantâ€™s at-will status; (2) did the Appellant remain an at-will employee when the Respondent placed him on probation; and (3) did the Respondent breach the alleged contract of probation in terminating the Appellantâ€™s employment?
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Raymond P. Nelson, Appellant,
v.
Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commission,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3882
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed October 
  25, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chalmers Carey Johnson, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Reginald W. Belcher, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

__________
ANDERSON, J.: Raymond P. Nelson 
  (Nelson) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Charleston 
  County Parks and Recreation Commission (CCPRC) on Nelsonâ€™s action for breach 
  of employment contract.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
CCPRC hired Nelson as a Maintenance Specialist 
  in May 1996, as an at-will employee, and terminated him on February 22, 2001, 
  following a nearly one-month probationary period for substandard performance.Â  
  For the last two years of Nelsonâ€™s employment with CCPRC, he worked as the James 
  Island County Maintenance Crew Chief.Â  The position required him to maintain 
  James Island County Parkâ€™s buildings, water park, campground, utilities, and 
  miscellaneous other structures.Â  The position required, among other things, 
  moderately heavy manual work, technical skills, supervisory knowledge, and the 
  ability to act independently on the job site.Â Â  
CCPRC terminated Nelsonâ€™s employment on or about 
  February 22, 2001, because his job performance progressively deteriorated for 
  at least the last eight months of his employment, despite CCPRCâ€™s continuing 
  efforts to encourage and prompt him to improve his poor and substandard performance.Â  
  CCPRC, through Nelsonâ€™s direct supervisor and two of CCPRCâ€™s long-tenured managers, 
  repeatedly attempted to correct Nelsonâ€™s excessive and unacceptable performance 
  problems by giving him several oral and written reprimands, counselings, and 
  warnings beginning in July of 2000. 
Nelson failed to show improvement in any of the 
  areas recommended for corrective action over the next six months. Â Effective 
  February 1, 2001 until July 31, 2001, CCPRC placed Nelson on six months probation, 
  expressly setting forth the improvements expected from him during that time 
  period, including providing his direct supervisor with a list of goals and objectives 
  by February 15, 2001.Â  Nelson interpreted the probationary status as creating 
  a six-month employment contract, though no particular document, oral statement, 
  or other evidence supported his position.Â Â  
Nelson failed to prepare the list of goals.Â  Furthermore, 
  his poor and inadequate planning resulted in his crew abandoning one work project 
  on February 8, 2001, and delaying two others.Â  On February 22, 2001, Nelsonâ€™s 
  direct supervisor and the two managers agreed to terminate Nelsonâ€™s employment 
  for â€œfailure to comply with requirements while on probationary status . . . 
  failure to perform work properly or follow work instruction.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Nelson filed a cause of action for wrongful termination 
  under an employment contract on October 31, 2001 against CCPRC, alleging CCPRC 
  altered his employment at-will status when it placed him on probation for his 
  progressively poor job performance.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment 
  to CCPRC and dismissed the case with prejudice. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment 
  motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial 
  court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary 
  judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. 
  Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 494, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002); Ferguson v. Charleston 
  Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 564 S.E.2d 94 (2002).Â  In determining 
  whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which 
  can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 
  350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 539 (2002); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 
  S.C. 332, 499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues 
  must go to the jury.Â  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 
  714, 718, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where 
  further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application 
  of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 
  S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, 
  and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against 
  the moving party.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 
  115, 120, 542 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Even when there is no dispute 
  as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be 
  drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  See Hall v. Fedor, 
  349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Moreover, summary 
  judgment is a drastic remedy which should be cautiously invoked so no person 
  will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.Â Â  Lanham 
  v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 336 (2002); 
  Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 
  271 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ ANALYSIS
I.Â  CCPRCâ€™s Actions in Putting Nelson 
  on Probation
Nelson maintains the circuit court erred in granting 
  summary judgment because, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to 
  Nelson as the nonmoving party, material issues of genuine fact exist concerning 
  whether Nelsonâ€™s probationary period altered his at-will employment status by 
  creating an employment contract between the parties.Â  We disagree. 
South Carolina recognizes the doctrine of employment 
  at-will.Â  See Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 
  516 S.E.2d 923 (1999).Â  This doctrine provides that a contract for permanent 
  employment is terminable at the pleasure of either party when unsupported by 
  any consideration other than the employerâ€™s duty to provide compensation in 
  exchange for the employeeâ€™s duty to perform a service or obligation.Â  See 
  id. â€œAt-will employment is generally terminable by either party at any 
  time, for any reason or no reason at all.â€Â  Id. at 334, 516 S.E.2d at 
  925.
South Carolina courts have carved out 
  exceptions to the at-will employment doctrine.Â  See Small v. Springs 
  Indus., Inc., 300 S.C. 481, 388 S.E.2d 808 (1990) (Small II); Davis 
  v. Orangeburg-Calhoun Law Enforcement Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 240, 542 S.E.2d 755 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  First, an employee has recourse against an employer for termination 
  in violation of public policy.Â  Small II, 300 S.C. at 484, 388 S.E.2d 
  at 810; Ludwick v. This Minute of Carolina, Inc., 287 S.C. 219, 337 S.E.2d 
  213 (1985).Â  Second, an at-will employee may not be terminated for exercising 
  constitutional rights.Â  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 335 n.3, 516 S.E.2d at 
  925 n.3; Moshtaghi v. The Citadel, 314 S.C. 316, 443 S.E.2d 915 (Ct. 
  App. 1994).Â  Finally, an employee has a cause of action against an employer 
  who contractually alters the at-will relationship and terminates the employee 
  in violation of the contract.Â  Davis, 344 S.C. at 246-47, 542 S.E.2d 
  at 758.Â  An employer and employee may contractually alter an at-will employment 
  relationship, and as a result, limit the ability of either party to terminate 
  the employment relationship without incurring liability.Â  See Small 
  v. Springs Indus., Inc., 292 S.C. 481, 357 S.E.2d 452 (1987) (Small I); 
  Baril, 352 S.C. at 281, 573 S.E.2d at 836; see also Culler 
  v. Blue Ridge Elec. Coop., Inc., 309 S.C. 243, 422 S.E.2d 91 (1992) (emphasizing 
  that the doctrine of employment at-will in its pure form allows an employer 
  to discharge an employee for good reason, no reason, or bad reason without incurring 
  liability).Â  For example, an employee handbook 
  [1]  may create a contract altering an at-will arrangement.Â  See 
  Small II, 300 S.C. at 484, 388 S.E.2d at 810; Baril, 352 S.C. 
  at 281, 573 S.E.2d at 836; see also Davis, 344 S.C. at 247, 542 
  S.E.2d at 758 (instructing that in certain situations, termination of at-will 
  employee may give rise to cause of action where at-will status of employee is 
  altered by terms of employee handbook).Â  Thus, an employerâ€™s written documents 
  can alter the at-will relationship and create an implied employment contract, 
  but only if the employer phrases the documentâ€™s language in mandatory terms 
  giving â€œrise to a promise, an expectation and a benefitâ€ to an employee.Â  Fleming 
  v. Borden, Inc., 316 S.C. 452, 463, 450 S.E.2d 589, 596 (1994).
The written reprimands, counselings, and warnings, 
  including the notification of probation letter, wholly lacked any mandatory 
  and promissory language guaranteeing Nelson continued or future employment.Â  
  CCPRCâ€™s policies and practices accurately reflected its at-will status throughout 
  Nelsonâ€™s tenure.Â  Furthermore, the CCPRC never promised or guaranteed that it 
  would ever employ Nelson on any basis except as an at-will employee, as admitted 
  by Nelson.Â Â  
Further, Nelson claims the following passage, from 
  CCPRCâ€™s â€œprobationâ€ section of the â€œDisciplinary Actionâ€ policy in the Personnel 
  Policies and Procedures Manual, constituted an implied contract:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 Probation:Â Â  This is defined as a specific 
  period of time usually 3-6 months, which shall cause the affected employee to 
  lose his or her regular status.Â  This may be used as an alternative action if 
  deemed appropriate.Â  Any infraction of Commission policies during this period 
  may result in more severe disciplinary action, depending on the facts of the 
  case.Â  Periods of disciplinary action shall be set forth in writing to the employee 
  referencing the reason and/or disciplinary action which invoked the period of 
  probation, notifying the employee that a special performance appraisal will 
  be conducted at the close of the probationary period.Â  An interim counseling 
  session must be conducted.Â  The use of probation must be approved by the Executive 
  Director.

This Court has applied standard principles of contract 
  interpretation in determining whether an employee handbook constitutes an employment 
  contract.Â  â€œWhere an action presents a question as to the construction of a 
  written contract and the language of the contract is clear and unambiguous,â€ 
  the alleged contract shall determine the â€œrights and obligations of the parties.â€Â  
  Holden v. Alice Mfg., Inc., 317 S.C. 215, 220, 452 S.E.2d 628, 631 (Ct. 
  App. 1994).Â  
The foregoing policy did not create an implied 
  contract.Â  In fact, it gave the Commission discretion to impose â€œmore severe 
  disciplinary actionâ€ during the probationary period.Â  The only mandatory language 
  used in the paragraph is in relation to the procedures that should be followed 
  when initially administering the probation.Â  
This case differs from Conner v. City of Forest 
  Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 560 S.E.2d 606 (2002), because the employer in Conner 
  used mandatory terms such as â€œshallâ€ and â€œwillâ€ in its employee handbook to 
  the extent that the grievance committee voted to reinstate the employee, proving 
  to the supreme court that â€œreasonable minds could differ.â€Â  Id. at 464, 
  560 S.E.2d at 612.Â  Not only did CCPRCâ€™s managers and Nelsonâ€™s direct supervisor 
  unanimously agree to terminate his employment, CCPRCâ€™s Executive Director upheld 
  Nelsonâ€™s termination upon his appeal.Â  Furthermore, unlike the employee in Conner, 
  Nelson reiterates that he was always employed on an at-will basis with CCPRC.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Nelson could not identify any particular document 
  or oral statement that supported his position.Â  During Nelsonâ€™s deposition, 
  he testified:

  
    
      
        Q. 
        Is there any other reason why you believe your status 
  as an at-will employee was altered?
      
      
         A.
        No.
      
      
        Q. 
        Is there any language, any written language, that you can show me in 
  any document that weâ€™ve traded back and forth in this case that would support 
  your position?
      
      
        A.
         Iâ€™m not sure.
      
      
        Q.
         Is there anything in the exhibit stack here today that you can go back 
  and show me that you think supports your position in that regard?
      
      
        A.
        Iâ€™m not sure if it will or not.
      
    
  

Even in his deposition, Nelson confirms 
  that there is no genuine issue as to a material fact concerning whether an employment 
  contract resulted from the probationary period.Â  For example, Nelson testified:

  
    
      
        Q.
         Weâ€™ll read that sentence [from the policy manual] 
  that starts: â€˜There is no particular order in which the above-noted disciplinary 
  actions must be used. The Commission reserves in its sole discretion the option 
  to utilize any disciplinary action at any time.â€™Â  [. . .] Doesnâ€™t that one paragraph 
  indicate to you that the Commission again could terminate someone at its sole 
  discretion at any time without following any particular steps?
      
      
        A.
         I guess so.
      
      
        Q. 
        . . . You would agree thatâ€™s what this 
  paragraph says?
      
      
        A.
        Yes.
      
      
        Q.
         And you understood this to be the policy of the Commission 
  throughout your employment there?
      
      
        A.
         Yes.
      
      
        Q. 
        . . . [Y]ou would agree that the Commission throughout 
  your employment maintained the right to terminate an employee at any time without 
  necessarily exhausting any particular steps or procedures?
      
      
        A.
         I donâ€™t think itâ€™s right.
      
      
        Q. 
         I understand that you donâ€™t think itâ€™s right, but 
  you understood that that was the policy of the Commission?
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        A.  
         Yes.
      
      
        Q. 
         And that was the policy throughout your employment 
  there?
      
      
        A.
         As far as I know.
      
    
  

Finding that an employment contract resulted from 
  this probationary period would lead to the result of giving greater rights and
